title: Native SACM reconciliation
content:
This section outlines some theories, recommendations, and considerations to ensure the reconciliation between existing CIs and CIs that get updated throughout the lifecycle (discovery, data import, manual change) works successfully in the Native SACM setup.  
 
With native SACM enabled, a federation is established and shows UD/UCMDB data in Service Management. The reconciliation of CIs is fully based on the reconciliation engine defined in UD/UCMDB, the Service Management internal reconciliation engine is no longer used in the Native SACM setup. 

How does reconciliation work in UD/UCMDB 

Let’s start with some theories first. Reconciliation is defined per CI type in UD/UCMDB. Each CI type may have different reconciliation rules. The reconciliation rule can be found on the Details tab of each CI type.

You can find the full documentation about how reconciliation in UD/UCMDB works by searching for "Data reconciliation" in the UCMDB documentation.

Reconciliation types

Based on key attributes 

This is a simple way to define the attributes to be reconciled. Simply select the attributes in scope. 

Based on the identification rule 

This option allows for a more comprehensive reconciliation logic. The logic is defined in an XML script and consists of the following elements. 

Each reconciliation rule is broken down into two parts and follows the outlined process. 

  1. Identification 
    A set of criteria that define all possible conditions to find all candidate CIs for matching to a newly introduced CI. The CI existing in the database is considered a candidate if one of the identification criteria matches. 
  2. Match
    1. Verification
      A set of criteria that are applied to all candidates left over after performing the identification (in the previous step). Match verification ends successfully only when all applied verification criteria are true or missing data (NA). 
    2. Validation
      An ordered set of criteria that are applied to all candidates left over after performing match verification. For each criterion, the following results are possible:

      • An “approve” result implies a match. 

      • A “contradict” result implies no match. 

      • Missing data (“unknown”) causes the reconciliation to proceed to the next criterion. If all validation criteria are NA, then all candidates left over after the match verification will be implied as "match."   


For more details, see UCMDB documentation. 

The following pages explain more details about the reconciliation recommendations for common Service Management entities and their related CI types. 

Service Management Entity 

UD/UCMDB CI Type(s) 

Actual Service 

BusinessService, InfrastructureService 

Service Component 

BusinessApplication 

SystemElement 

RunningSoftware, ApplicationSystems, AWS Resource, Database Resource, WebService Resource, Cloud Service 

Device 

Node 

Considerations for Service Management

To ensure Services and CIs created in Service Management are successfully reconciled when CIs are added, updated, imported, or discovered by UD/UCMDB, we recommend that you review the defined reconciliation rules in UD/UCMDB.  

In case the out-of-the-box reconciliation rules are used, the following key attributes should be populated on the Service Management side (through either UI or business rules) to ensure reconciliation can identify a match of the CI. 
 

Actual Service  

Business Service 

Actual Services of subtype Business Service map to the CI Type Business Service in UD/UCMDB. Such CIs are reconciled based on the Service Management Display Label attribute which is mapped to the UD/UCMDB name attribute.  

Service Management attribute 

UCMDB attribute 

Remarks 

Display Label 

name 

A Business Service is identified by its name.  
Two similarly identified Business Service instances are considered to be different entities in case of a mismatch of the Party that owns these instances.

Note: The “Party that owns the service” can't be set by Service Management, but might be used when creating or editing CIs directly in UD/UCMDB. 

Infrastructure Service 

Actual Services of subtype Infrastructure Service map to the CI Type Infrastructure Service in UD/UCMDB. Such CIs are reconciled based on the Service Management Display Label attribute which is mapped to the UD/UCMDB name attribute.   

Service Management attribute 

UCMDB attribute 

Remarks 

Display Label 

name 

An Infrastructure Service is identified by its name. Two similarly identified infrastructure services are considered different CIs in case of a mismatch of either: 

  • The Party that owns the infrastructure service.

or  

  • At least one name of any Configuration Item that's linked to the infrastructure service by a containment link.  

  • At least one name of any Configuration Item that's linked to the infrastructure service by a usage link. 

Note: The “Party that owns the service” and “Linked Configuration” item logic can't be set in the Service Management UI, but might be used when creating or editing CIs directly in UD/UCMDB. 

Service Component  

Service Components map to the CI Type Business Application in UD/UCMDB. Such CIs are reconciled based on the Service Management Display Label attribute which is mapped to the UD/UCMDB name attribute.  

Service Management attribute 

UCMDB attribute 

Remarks

Display Label 

name 

A Business Application is identified by its name. Two Business Application instances are considered to be different if they are owned by different Party objects, or if they have different Application ID. 
 
Note: The Party and Application ID attribute can't be set by Service Management, but might be used when creating or editing CIs directly in UCMDB UI. 

System Element 

System Elements map to the following CI types in UD/UCMDB. 

  • RunningSoftware 

  • ApplicationSystems 

  • AWS Resource 

  • Database Resource 

  • WebService Resource 

  • Cloud Service 

Service Elements can't be created manually in Service Management since each CI type in UD/UCMDB has different requirements to successfully create such CIs. In this area, the system fully relies on the data entered into UD/UCMDB. Therefore, no additional recommendations for the reconciliation requirements are given here. 

For details, see System elements.

Device 

Device records map to the CI type Node in UD/UCMDB. The reconciliation rules for the Node CI type are very comprehensive since the reconciliation is based on many different criteria.  

This rule includes the following Service Management attributes for the Identification phase. 

Service Management attribute 

UCMDB attribute 

Host name

name 

Net Bios Name 

net_bios_name 

Bios Serial Number 

bios_serial_number 

Bios UUID 

bios_uuid 

Serial Number 

serial_number 

Bios Asset Tag 

bios_asset_tag 

Primary DNS Name 

primary_dns_name 

The following attributes should be considered as key attributes for the Match reconciliation phase. It's recommended to ensure that as many as possible of them are populated in Service Management, to get the best reconciliation results. 

In general, the Node reconciliation ideally has 1 of the following set of key attributes provided to achieve the best results.  

The reconciliation rule is run in the order as documented in the table below. The execution stops on a candidate CI if the first match is found. 

 Service Management attribute(s) 

UCMDB attribute 

Service Management attributes available from 

Remarks

Host name 

Bios serial number 

name 

bios_serial_number 
 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

Host name 

Serial number 

name 

serial_number 
 
  • Service Management creation UI 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

This attribute combination is typically used when having physical machines, like servers, laptops, or desktops where the serial number is known. 

Host name 

Bios UUID 

name 

bios_uuid 
 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

Host name 

Bios Asset Tag 

name 

bios_asset_tag 
 
  • Service Management creation UI 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

In case the Bios Asset Tag is known, it's another attribute that can be used directly when creating a CI. 

Net Bios Name 

Bios serial number 

net_bios_name 

bios_serial_number 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

Net Bios Name 

Serial number 

net_bios_name 

serial_number 
 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

Net Bios Name 

Bios UUID 

net_bios_name 

bios_uuid 
 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

Net Bios Name 

Bios Asset Tag 

net_bios_name 

bios_asset_tag 
 
  • Service Management update UI 
  • Business Rule 

Remarks: 

Ideally, the reconciliation happens against the attributes listed in the table above. However, in some cases, these details can't be provided. The following remarks highlight some additional options and considerations.

Host name is an attribute in Service Management that maps to the “name” attribute in UD/UCMDB. In case only this attribute is provided and no serial number or bios asset tag is set to match the standard reconciliation patterns, the behavior is as follows:

  1. The Identification phase will select the existing CI as a candidate based on the name.
  2. The Match – Verification phase will keep the candidate.
  3. The Match – Validation phase can't match this CI based on the name only because there is no standard reconciliation pattern for the name attribute only.
  4. Best case there is only 1 candidate left and the system will merge the candidate CI with the new CI. 

    Attention: In case more than one candidate is chosen in step 1, the new CI isn't merged with the existing CIs, but added into the database. 
    In case the standard behavior isn't sufficient, it's required to adjust the reconciliation rules. Please make sure the reconciliation logic is known and well understood before changing something.

OS Type is an attribute in Service Management that maps to the “os_family” attribute in UD/UCMDB. This attribute is validated at the Match – Verification phase. In case this attribute is set for example to “Windows” and then discovery returns a CI where this value is set to “Linux,” but the name and serial number attribute are matching, the CI is not considered for reconciliation and is removed from the candidate list.
